subtitle.text: The Boy and the Cats
There once was a boy named Sesshu.
His parents were very poor and they could not feed him.
They sent Sesshu to a temple to become a monk.
But Sesshu did not want to be a monk.
He only wanted to draw pictures of cats.
"I love drawing cats," he told anyone who asked.
During study time, the monks always told him to stop drawing.
"Sesshu, pay attention."
"Sesshu, put down your brush."
"Sesshu, stop that."
But Sesshu didn't stop.
One day, the oldest monk at the temple saw him drawing in a book.
"Sesshu," said the monk, "that's not allowed."
"I'm sorry," said Sesshu.
The monk saw then that Sesshu was not meant to be a monk.
"Are you happy here?" he asked the boy.
"No. I want to be an artist," said Sesshu.
"Go home and talk with your parents," the monk said kindly.
Sesshu began to walk home, but the way was long and he got lost.
When he saw an old temple .. he decided to stop there for the night.
He didn't know it, but the temple was haunted.
KNOCK, KNOCK, KNOCK.
"Hello? IS anuone home?" he asked.
No one answered.
Sesshu went inside.
It was very dirty, and he felt lonely.
He comforted himself by drawing cats all over the walls.
Finally, his last candle melted away.
"Yum, yum!" he heard.
"Is someone there?" he asked.
No one answered.
Sesshu lay down to sleep.
He heard something walking closer.
TIP, TAP, TIP, TAP.
Sesshu opened his eyes and saw the shadow of a monster rat.
"Help!" he cried.
Then Sesshu heard another noise.
"Meow."
On the wall, a spotted cat drawing began to movel
It twitched its whiskers.
It winked atÂ·Sesshu.
The cat jumped off the wall and hissed, "Get out of here, rat!"
But the rat only laughed.
"I'm much stronger than you." it said.
Then all the cats on the wall began to move.
Are you stronger than all of us? said one very large cat.
"Uh, oh," said the rat.
The cats jumped toward the rat.
"Get out of herel" they screeched.
"Eee! Eee! Eee!" screamed the rat, and it ran back to the shadows.
The cats purred as loud as thunder.
"You saved me!" said Sesshu.
"But ... you're just drawings," he said.
Maybe we are, said the spotted cat.
And maybe_ we're not, said the large cat.
Then the cats watched over Sesshu for the rest of the night.
When he woke up, Sesshu saw the cat drawings on the wall.
It must've been a dream, he said.
But nearby was a real cat, and Sesshu followed it out of the temple.
The cat led him to the home of a great artist.

Sesshu showed the artist a sketch, and the old man saw the
boy's talent.
"You'll be a great artist someday," he told Sesshu.
"Will you teach me?" asked Sesshu.
"Yes," said the old artist, smiling.
"Come inside."
And so Sesshu studied art and indeed became a great artist.
But even then, he still loved to draw cats.
